content.title: Derwent House, an arty Victorian House

introduction.small: Very close to Kloof Street and yet very quiet, Derwent House is best enjoyed as a loving couple in one of the locally decorated rooms, or as a family in one of the two apartments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Derwent House, an arty Victorian House

paragraphs.text:
In a large Victorian family house typical of Cape Town, and only a stone's throw from the lively Kloof Street, you will find the Derwent House, a hybrid between a guesthouse and a boutique hotel. Nine rooms and two apartments – perfect configuration for family travels – are spread across the house. Its inhabitants for a day will love its quietness, swimming pool and green gardens, as well as the fireplace on cool nights. Art lovers will take a fancy at the various works on display in the lobby, transformed in this instance into an art gallery, or in the bedrooms where Derwent House sheds a light on local artists and craftsmen – Carole Nevin, Joanna Orr, Sue Jowell… It is even possible to leave with a favourite of yours, like the colourful antelope painting hanging above your bed. Of course, you will be privy to nature's own work of art, from a private terrace that gives onto Table Mountain in the early morning.

content.title: Yours Truly, beer with a view

introduction.small: Major hangout in Cape Town, night and day, Yours Truly is ideal to sip on a cup of coffee or gather for pre-dinner drinks in a wonderful setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yours Truly, beer with a view

paragraphs.text:
From morning coffees to wild early night drinks, Yours Truly is a genuine institution in Cape Town. This hybrid spot, between tea salon and bar, is open from 6 a.m. to midnight. Located in the Tamboerskloof neighbourhood, it usually welcomes foreign students, hipsters, tourists and other curious patrons with a relaxed atmosphere. This eclectic clientele heads to the rooftop when the sun sets: under a green pergola, the wood-covered roof takes on a German biergarten look.

While you wait for the unique panorama to be adorned with the last rays of the sun, pizzas will be shared as pints of beer and glasses of wine clink together. It is worth noting Yours Truly serves its own house wine – Truly Wines – in both white and red, to be enjoyed in moderation of course. As night sets in, the rooftop shines even brighter, enlivened by the sounds of acoustic concerts or crazy DJ sets.

content.title: At Zeitz, African contemporary art is given pride of place

introduction.small: Opened in Cape Town in 2017, this museum devoted to African contemporary art enjoys special architecture and is the first of its kind on the continent.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Zeitz, African contemporary art is given pride of place

paragraphs.text:
The building stands out amid the Victoria & Waterfront urban landscape, in the heart of Cape Town's historical centre, which is actually the most visited site in South Africa. The Zeitz, Museum of Contemporary Art Africa, took up residence in a decommissioned grain silo built in the 1920s. The redevelopment was conceived by renowned architect Thomas Heatherwick to emulate London's Tate Modern, established in a former power plant. A luminous atrium has been sculpted out of the silo's cylinders to welcome visitors. About a hundred art galleries spread over nine floors include for most part philanthropist Jochen Zeitz's collection, after who the museum was named. However, the masterpiece seems to be the building itself, with its neo-industrial look and kaleidoscopic picture windows, similar to the shape of a jewel. A guided tour is even devoted to discovering its architecture, to better understand the value of this already historical monument.

Zeitz MOCAA (Museum of Contemporary Art Africa)

Waterfront

content.title: Journey into South African artist Irma Stern's house

introduction.small: In Cape Town's Rosebank neighbourhood, the museum dedicated to Irma Stern is located in the 20th-century expressionist artist's home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Journey into South African artist Irma Stern's house

paragraphs.text:
Hidden behind a high wall, the Irma Stern museum is invisible from the street. It pays tribute to the South African artist, all in the midst of her last home. Visitors will first have a look at some of her first portraits and landscapes brought back from Zanzibar, a country the artist loved. Drawings, paintings, ceramics and sculptures are to be found along the other rooms, the dining room and the art studio. Associated with the German expressionist movement, the artist unveils colourful paintings at her home, showcasing traditional African elements. Her personal collection gathered during her travels is also an essential part of the tour, including a mid-19th-century Congolese tool from Buli Master. Finally, enter the world of Irma Stern's own world and visit the reconstructed art studio, where you will see the easel, palette, tubes of paint and brushes she used at the time. During the tour, you will experience a strange feeling: the artist passed away in 1966 but you can almost sense she's ready to resume her work.

Irma Stern Museum

content.title: Royale Eatery, king of the burger… and vegetarian cuisine

introduction.small: The Royale Eatery collects awards! On the programme: succulent meat as well as vegetarian dishes, brownies and a roof terrace. Indulge yourself!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Royale Eatery, king of the burger… and vegetarian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Red meat lovers, here you are served! The Classic Royale (a 160g pure beef patty in their delicious basting sauce, garlic aioli, lettuce, tomato, caramelized onion and gherkins) patiently awaits you at the Royale Eatery.

This restaurant located in the centre of Cape Town does not skimp on its offering: over 50 varieties of burgers, including ostrich. Open carnivores and vegetarian-friendly, the team proudly offers a selection of vegetarian dishes – one of the largest in the country. You will not be able to resist their Zelig, homemade sesame encrusted falafel patty topped with a crunch salsa and hummus.

After the meal, drag yourself through the hustle and bustle to reach the roof terrace. There you will sip a light cocktail before facing the other pleasures of very lively Long Street. Unless you opt for the bar where, with any luck, you will be surprised by the hectic rhythm of a live band.

content.title: Kloof Street House, The Urban Oasis

introduction.small: Between a house from another era and a wild garden, Kloof Street House possesses the indescribable charm of an exceptional location.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kloof Street House, The Urban Oasis

paragraphs.text:
A restored Victorian building, marvellous eclectic garden: Kloof Street House takes on the poetry of a place that experiences a new life after having lived many others.

Located in the Gardens district, enter a welcoming universe with colours abound. Pendant chandeliers and tealights adorn the place with a warm light.

On the menu, cuisine from around the world: Moroccan-style lamb, couscous seeds and red cabbage or quinoa moussaka, baba ganoush, arugula and parmesan cheese. After the main course, finish with a dark chocolate fondant with homemade toasted marshmallow and marshmallow ice cream, subtly regressive, yet delicious!

At the heart of the bustling Kloof Street, choose between a candlelight dinner amidst lush vegetation or listening to a jazz concert on a Sunday at brunch time.

content.title: An athletic outing to Signal Hill and Lion's Head

introduction.small: Lion's Head overlooks Cape Town from Table Mountain National Park. Put on your hiking shoes!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An athletic outing to Signal Hill and Lion's Head

paragraphs.text:
Named “Leeuwen Kop” by the first Dutch settlers in the 17th century, this geological formation resembling a lion's head – hence the name – is now a national park and entices the curiosity and daring of many hikers. The panoramic views of the Atlantic coast, golden beaches and the city itself are exceptional from Signal Hill, Devil's Peak and Table Mountain. Climb the heather walls of the massif and reach the summit of this rocky peak with a lion's head for which Signal Hill is the body.

Set off to conquer a grandiose Africa that passing tourists discover during sunny or nocturnal getaways. Camps Bay, Clifton, and Green Point are within easy reach of your hands (on rope ladders) and feet (to climb the steepest trails). The day rises over Cape Town and bathes the most intrepid with morning light.

content.title: Stellenbosch, the sweet perfume of Europe

introduction.small: Stellenbosch is a little South African gem that plays with genres and dances with vines. Close to Cape Town, come on board to discover a unique city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stellenbosch, the sweet perfume of Europe

paragraphs.text: Founded more than three centuries ago, Stellenbosch is among the oldest cities in South Africa. Along the Eerste River, Stellenbosch sets itself apart with its "Cape Dutch" architecture of grand houses with white façades and mouldings. This colonial style is the product of a multicultural marriage brought about by the Dutch who imported fragments of their European culture in the 17th century. The thatched roofs and lime walls of these South African homes mirror Amsterdam's town houses. A touristic jewel for the region, Stellenbosch is lined with centuries-old oak trees and thriving vineyards. The Mediterranean climate allows winemaking to grow, and the region has attracted lots of tourists to its wine route, established in 1971. Amid its green valleys, domains and wine estates abound with cellars open to the public. A great tasting is just around the corner!

content.title: Exclusive hike and urban winery experience in Cape Town's vineyards

introduction.small: Enjoy extraordinary views from the top of Table Mountain and come back down for an elegant picnic at an “urban” vineyard in the heart of the south African metropolis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Exclusive hike and urban winery experience in Cape Town's vineyards

paragraphs.text:
Cape Town features outstanding landscapes, picturesque neighbourhoods, significant historic sites and superb food, including excellent wines. For a memorable day enjoying some of the best experiences Cape Town has to offer, embark on a one-of-a-kind sportive adventure that will take you to the summit of Table Mountain for a breath-taking vista. An unforgettable experience!

After a leisurely hike up to the top of the Front Table, take in the dramatic views of the city's skyline, spot Robben Island - where Nelson Mandela infamously spent 18 years in a prison cell - and marvel at the stunning viewpoint over Table Bay. Catch a cable car down for a last glimpse at the City Bowl, and a panorama over the Cape Peninsula and the majestic Twelve Apostles.

Back in the colourful streets of Cape Town, discover a hidden gem: an urban vineyard, where you will have the unique opportunity to taste some of their limited production wines, including South Africa's flagship grape, pinotage, and pair them with a scrumptious picnic basket that you will surely appreciate after having worked up an appetite with your morning hike.

Cape Town is a must visit destination for nature and wine enthusiasts as it combines the best of both worlds thanks to its close proximity to the Cape Winelands, their rolling vineyards, towering mountains, historic wine estates and more.

Wine Paths

https://www.winepaths.com/

content.title: Muizenberg, or the call of the sea

introduction.small: For lying about in the sun, diving into the ocean, or catching a wave, the Muizenberg beach is the best option.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Muizenberg, or the call of the sea

paragraphs.text:
Muizenberg, lined by colourful Victorian beach cabins, contains one of the longest beaches near Cape Town and has been a destination for generations of beachgoers.

For many, surfing in South Africa started here. A legendary beach, the waves are suitable for beginners, and surf schools have multiplied. One of the first, Gary's Surf School, teaches introductory classes right on the main beach, called 'Surfer's Corner', where the smoothed-out waves won't scare the novices. More advanced surfers may head to Kalk Bay, Longbeach, Scarborough, Dungeons, or the aptly named Dangers Beach. Keep your eyes open for the Great White Sharks, however.

At Muizenberg a net is generally in use to keep them away, but the Shark Spotters, a world first, are also watching the coast. If you see a red flag, it means there is a high danger of sharks, while a white flag means that one has been spotted.

content.title: Kirstenbosch Botanical Garden, suspended between sky and sea.

introduction.small: Need some green? Then head to this garden suspended between sky and sea, in Cape Town's chic suburb.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kirstenbosch Botanical Garden, suspended between sky and sea.

paragraphs.text:
Talking to the tips of the trees on the back of a curved serpent of timber and steel… that was the dream of a gardener who was madly in love with the sky. And you get to share in the experience. The Kirstenbosch Centenary Tree Canopy Walkway, a 130-metre long suspended pathway opened in 2014, is raised 12 metres above the green ‘sea' of the gardens. This extraordinary garden includes 9,000 South African plants, almost half of the 22,000 species inventoried in the country.

If an earthly paradise exists, it is here in the sounds of the leaves blowing in the wind, the exotic songs of birds and the flapping of the wings of butterflies. In the summer, the notes of major South African musicians can be heard during the Summer Sunset Concerts. You can admire the view while letting yourself be transported by the rhythm of the melodies.

After the show, have a look at the garden's sculptures and discover medicinal plants. Guided tours are possible.

content.title: Franschhoek, the French corner

introduction.small: Among the vineyards near Cape Town, a small village recalls the South of France: welcome to Franschhoek.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Franschhoek, the French corner

paragraphs.text:
An idyllic village, worthy of a postcard, surrounded by wine estates with Cape Dutch architecture, Franschhoek (Afrikaans for 'French corner'), looks every bit the southern French village. Bastille Day is celebrated every year with blue, white, and red flags floating gaily overhead, and the numerous restaurants all have French names.

But never fear; these are English speakers, as the first generation of Huguenots quickly assimilated the Afrikaans language, and subsequent generations learned English as well.

Of the French spirit, the love of good food and wine was not lost however. Franschhoek has the reputation for the best gastronomic offerings in the country. As for wine, discover all its secrets and aromas during an unusual visit on board the Franschhoek Wine tram. From Cape Town to France in just over an hour, it's the perfect side trip.

Franschhoek Wine Valley
62 Huguenot Road

content.title: On the wine trail

introduction.small: Escape, if only for a day, to these ancestral vineyards, just an hour from the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the wine trail

paragraphs.text:
At the doors of Cape Town, Bacchus himself seems to have shaped the hillsides. Later, Dutch and French immigrants helped him along. As the Dutch prepared the land for agriculture, they found that the ground was perfect for vineyards.

And when the Huguenots were chased out of France after the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, they landed in South Africa, with grapevines in their suitcases. To this day, there are many French descendants and much good wine. Whether or not you are a wine lover, the stunning landscapes are worth the detour.

In just a small area around Stellenbosch, Paarl, and Franschhoek, enchanting green valleys are covered with vineyards of Syrah, Malbec, Chenin blanc and Cabernet. The best palates will be able to taste the subtle blends of these grapes, but anyone can explore the vineyards by travelling on foot or by bicycle.

https://www.winelands.co.za/

content.title: The rhythms of Cape Town

introduction.small: Discover Cape Town in the most unusual manner… Listen to music directly at locals for a night. Various genres available!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The rhythms of Cape Town

paragraphs.text:
A musician plays a tune for you, at his home. This rare moment is brought to you by Coffeebeans Routes, a group that loves nothing less than to show you Cape Town off the beaten track. The Jazz Safari tour offers you the possibility of sharing a meal and an evening with an artist under his very own roof.

Classic jazz notes subtly mingle with those of the local Cape jazz, goema, in a fascinating musical dialogue. The second act of the evening may continue at a concert or at another jazz musician's home. The new Choral Music Tour lets you in on private concerts. So much invisible sheet music that lets you read the city differently.

Exchange is king and you will go home with a wealth of experiences. Coffeebeans Routes also offers other day trips and even entire vacations on a range of themes: local cuisine, design, art, wine, the explosion of craft breweries or 'Township Futures' to discuss these sprawling areas and how they will be part of tomorrow's Cape Town. Take your pick!

content.title: Pod Boutique Hotel: the ocean at the end of the road

introduction.small: A designer, chic and eco-friendly address for some serious cocooning.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pod Boutique Hotel: the ocean at the end of the road

paragraphs.text:
Opulence perfectly suits the minimalist lines of this boutique hotel facing the Atlantic, Table Mountain, and Lion's Head. Perched high above Camps Bay, there are 17 rooms here in a palette of granite, slate, and glass. Greg Wright Architects placed wooden box-like structures on the hill into which the rooms were fitted. The wood and stone combine with the white bedding to make for a surprisingly warm room in the spirit of a welcoming loft.

Less visible but still environmentally friendly, the hotel aimed at using green energy sources during its construction, including solar panels to heat the water. Make the most of the activities offered by the hotel during your stay: visit the Cape Peninsula, tour the vineyards, or head out on a day's safari.

Appreciate the lounge for late departures after checkout, which is all you need to cool off and shower up before getting to your long-haul flight.

content.title: La Grenadine Petit Hotel, French country in downtown Cape Town

introduction.small: A house with a French accent and a laidback attitude for a bohemian journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Grenadine Petit Hotel, French country in downtown Cape Town

paragraphs.text:
She is an actress and dancer; he is a sociologist in training. This lovely French couple opened this bed and breakfast on an old 1850s farm located in the middle of Cape Town. With some of their vinyl collection to entertain your ears and a book to occupy your mind, they hope you feel right at home. French style encounters South African design with furniture unearthed at flea markets, pillows in ‘Wax' African fabrics, and lampshades conceived by local designers.

Unsurprisingly, the entire setting feels like a vacation home. The perfect luxury? It might be pulling a ripe pomegranate (grenadine in French) from the tree in the charming garden. And if you are too lazy to harvest the passion fruit, lemons, and guava yourself, you will find them on the breakfast table.

As for the library, an oasis within the oasis, it invites you to come and borrow whatever you like; the books here are available in several languages.

content.title: Tribe 112, for coffee and a boost

introduction.small: In the midst of some powerful two-wheelers, this café serves up some fuel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tribe 112, for coffee and a boost

paragraphs.text:
They need gasoline to drive like others need coffee to walk. Here among the new and vintage motorcycles at the clever BMW Donford Motorrad, you can also grab a cuppa Joe. BMW has joined up with Tribe café to offer excellent coffee amid their thoroughbred racing motorbikes and black leather clothes for the world of the road.

Tribe roasts coffee from around the world; the aromas and flavours bring chocolate, cinnamon, nuts, and truffle oil to mind.

Come on in for your choice of breakfast (scrambled eggs and bacon, avocado toasts, granola bowls, fruits and yoghurt, banana bread and cinnamon) or lunch (Thai chicken curry, roasted butternut and camembert cheese or burger). You can finish off with a delicious espresso full of caffeine before hitting the road with a turbo boost.

content.title: A culinary tour seasoned with a thousand spices in Bo-Kaap

introduction.small: Cape Malay cuisine is home in the Bo-Kaap neighbourhood. Discover a melting pot of flavours!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A culinary tour seasoned with a thousand spices in Bo-Kaap

paragraphs.text:
For 35 years, Zainie Misbach has used the depths of her pots and pans to prepare Cape Malay dishes of all kinds. With an Indonesian heritage and Indian, African, and European touches, “This is the cuisine of Cape Town” she says.

This grand dame of the kitchens worked for many years in her parents' restaurant before offering gourmet visits throughout her neighbourhood, Bo-Kapp, the only non-white area not to have been destroyed during apartheid.

A quick stop in the spice shop before cooking and then Zainie welcomes the group to her home, where the cooking class can start. On the menu, chicken curry, rootis, samosas and dhaltjies. If you are not up for cooking, you can also choose a guided tour throughout the neighbourhood, followed by a sit-down lunch at Zainie's house.

content.title: The Taproom at Devil's Peak Brewing Company, Cape Town's beer

introduction.small: The Taproom at Devil's Peak Brewing Company, Cape Town's beer

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Taproom at Devil's Peak Brewing Company, Cape Town's beer

paragraphs.text:
In Cape Town, craft beer is causing quite a froth; it has never been so trendy. Several breweries have appeared in recent years, including Devil's Peak Brewing Company in 2012. Success was immediate.

In this long oval room with large windows, some old photos hang on the walls and mismatched furniture provides a bohemian atmosphere. Shoes seem to have been forgotten in a corner (oops, no, this is the decoration!).

The place is a den of hipsters, sure, but they are not the only patrons, as many established Cape Towners come to taste the amber and blonde ales brewed on the premises. You can also down some hake with aioli, the hot dog of the month and, for vegetarians, oven-cooked beetroot and sundried tomatoes.

content.title: Superette, where the locavores eat

introduction.small: Cape Town's trendy restaurant where you can eat healthy and delicious foods.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Superette, where the locavores eat

paragraphs.text:
Brought to you by Justin Rhodes and Cameron Munro, the two founders of the famous Neighbourgoods Market, this café brings you the farm-to-table goodness of many of the market purveyors, meaning if you come on a Saturday morning (market day), you can shop for your cake and eat it too...

You will delight in the atmosphere at the Superette, with its Brooklyn vibe and decor: polished concrete floors, exposed brick walls, and white tiles, not to mention the touch offered by canary yellow chairs bright enough to rival the South African sun. Good humour is evident on every face, even though some of the other guests may be hiding behind computers, making the most of their carryout work.

On your plate, fresh and seasonal products are the stars, from a mix of crunchy salads and prepared sandwiches to small homemade dishes. Rhodes and Munro have helped Woodstock get out of the shadows, and now they have also opened the What If the World contemporary art gallery nearby. Superette is ideal for breakfast, when you can dive into the honey taken directly from the hive, or for lunch, alongside other late risers.

content.title: Cape Heritage, sleep in the city centre

introduction.small: In this old house, you will perhaps feel the beating heart of old Cape Town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cape Heritage, sleep in the city centre

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of downtown, this historic hotel overlooks Bree Street, where trendy bars and restaurants flourish. From here you can easily explore the centre on foot. The building dates to the 18th century, as does its grapevine, among the first planted in Cape Town, which today produces nearly 20 litres of wine each year. Located on the restored Heritage Square, the hotel is a living link to the shops of yesteryear that sold tobacco, bread, ropes and even firearms.

Within its walls, the sounds of the square, once full of pedestrians and shoppers, still echo. In the rooms, the wooden floors creak under foot, and the walls are covered with photos and works by contemporary artists. No room is the same.

The decoration also showcases local crafts from the townships. The hotel is very involved in the community, particularly through the Zip Zap Circus Association, which helps struggling children. You can attend the circus' shows by booking in advance.

content.title: La Colombe, with a view of the countryside

introduction.small: Book without delay a table at this elegant restaurant for delicate, refined dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Colombe, with a view of the countryside

paragraphs.text:
La Colombe is a restaurant up to its neck in awards, so remember to book well in advance. Of course, the main reason to make sure you plan ahead lies in the outstanding cuisine of James Gaag. Another reason to come: the restaurant has the feel of a private balcony overlooking the lush Constantia Valley of Hout Bay. Resembling a contemporary lodge dressed in white and grey, La Colombe is exceptionally beautiful.

The chef creates pure gold on the plate, often full of sweet surprises. The fish amuse-bouche is presented in a pretty tin of tuna. When you open it you'll see the tantalising tuna preparation with Asian influences that will delight your palate.

Then on to some tuna blind tasting, a marlin tataki, the catch of the day cooked in a Malaysian style or shrimp with strained yoghurt. Herbs come directly from the establishment's small vegetable garden and several vegetarian menus are also available. And what about the service? It's as perfect as the food and as lovely as the view.

content.title: Belmond Mount Nelson Hotel, a dreamlike oasis

introduction.small: At the foot of Table Mountain, this historic hotel is also a well-known address for Cape Towners taking high tea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belmond Mount Nelson Hotel, a dreamlike oasis

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1899, this hotel was one of the first in South Africa to provide running water to its guests. Both hot and cold no less, something that was a real luxury for the time. Many historical figures have laid down their heads there: Winston Churchill, the Prince of Wales, the Dalai Lama and various others…

Today, it displays the elegance of its 198 rooms and suites in the middle of a four-hectare park of perfectly tended lawns. Under the palm trees, two swimming pool areas invite you to take a dip or to give in to laziness on the sun loungers. The Belmond Mount Nelson has incredible charm and offers impeccable service. Behind its rose colonial facade, one can indeed see life through rose-coloured glasses.

At High Tea, the hot drink of the house comes with cucumber sandwiches, cupcakes, and melktert, the typical South African dessert.

content.title: Wish U Were Here, a lovely invitation

introduction.small: In this trendy inn, everyone from backpackers to businesspeople and families meet up around a delicious barbecue.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wish U Were Here, a lovely invitation

paragraphs.text:
In the lively Woodstock neighbourhood, Wish U Were Here incarnates the new trend of crossing youth hostels with traditional hotels. You can choose your room from a variety of styles: with bunk beds (practical for a family) or a private room with a shared or a private bathroom. The hotel is full of imagination, and with good reason since a film designer handled the decoration. The 21 different rooms have everything from a boat-shaped bed to a mini-golf course. Chic or rustic, it's all up to you.

All rooms have recycled materials too. The owners wanted to create a unique experience and they have. They also included a braai, the famous South African traditional barbecue, where guests can meet and chat around the hot coals for a ‘warm' atmosphere.

Don't forget to pick up your meat at the Saturday morning Neighbourgoods Market! It's the perfect excuse to shop like a local.

content.title: District Six Museum, the neighbourhood that is no more

introduction.small: Discover life under the laws of apartheid at one of Cape Town's most fascinating museums.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: District Six Museum, the neighbourhood that is no more

paragraphs.text:
Behind the door of a former church of the Methodist Mission, a dark page of history is on display. Under apartheid, a 1966 law declared District Six “Whites Only”, all non-Whites being undesirables in the eyes of the government of the time.

This museum explains the history of the multi-ethnic neighbourhood here that was entirely destroyed. The 60,000 inhabitants who were expulsed were, for the most part, relocated to the townships on the periphery of the city. Photographs and personal objects are complemented with poignant testimonies from former residents in this living exhibit.

If the museum renders homage to all of these broken lives, it is in speaking with the staff that you can better grasp daily life under apartheid. A beautiful place of memory.

District Six Museum

content.title: Woodstock, Cape Town's Brooklyn

introduction.small: This neighbourhood is a rising star and a gold mine for exhibits, shopping, and flea market finds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Woodstock, Cape Town's Brooklyn

paragraphs.text:
Just a few years ago, few people ventured out to Woodstock, then considered far too dangerous. But everything began to change in 2006 when the Neighbourgoods Market started on Saturday mornings (9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.) at The Old Biscuit Mill.

Since then, the stalls of this market have continued to multiply, and they now overflow, with upwards of 100 traders selling sun-drenched tomatoes, cheese with enticing aromas, various kinds of organic bread, and craft beers. Once shoppers have filled their weekly shopping needs, they can check out the fashion and crafts on hand. Then Cape Town residents and travellers alike can nibble on some of the delicious, and often wholesome, goodies at a long wooden table shared in a friendly atmosphere.

Not surprisingly, all around The Old Biscuit Mill boutiques of young designers, art galleries, antique shops, and other outlets have flourished. Do not miss The Woodstock Exchange (nicknamed WEX) and The Woodstock Foundry, two other creative spots, right nearby.

content.title: Paranga, the cool summer spot

introduction.small: On the famous Camps Bay strip, the Paranga offers sunny local cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paranga, the cool summer spot

paragraphs.text:
On the seafront in Camps Bay, the Paranga is the perfect place to see and be seen. Billing itself as ‘Cape Town's coolest culinary experience', here you can admire the evening sun diving into the water, just across the street from the Paranga terrace. The colours of the stretched-canvas sky in summertime match the honey-tinted stone walls to perfection.

Go for the grilled kingklip (a local cusk eel, famous for its white and firm flesh) and shellfish, the beef carpaccio, the goat cheese and apple kataïfi, the butcher's cut or vegetarian wok with soba noodles. The offerings for early risers? How about a breakfast featuring a coconut and passion fruit smoothie alongside Eggs Royal with smoked salmon and hollandaise, or fruit with pomegranate seed, Bulgarian yoghurt and granola. The cuisine, sourced locally, lives up to the view, which is saying a lot!

content.title: Merchants on Long, ethical and chic concept store

introduction.small: The best in local and sustainable creations is available here in this beautiful early 20th-century shop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Merchants on Long, ethical and chic concept store

paragraphs.text:
The art scene is brimming with creativity in Africa. Since 2010, Hanneli Ruppert has been dishing out the best in the same way a locavore chef does. Savoir-faire and imagination contribute to her successful gathering of the best from the entire continent: quality, colourful, joyful, “Made in Africa” objects, often made of natural materials.

Her concept store offers elegant fashions with refined accessories produced with an aim for sustainable development and traceability. A big hurrah to the MaXhosa brand by Laduma that explores the Xhosa culture through graphic printed knits, or the Ghanian YEVU label for its reinterpretation of traditional African fabrics.

On the walls, the black-and-white studio shots of the famous Malik Sidibé of Mali or the fantastic portraits in bright colours, with traditional design borders from the Moroccan Hassan Hajjaj, testify to African life through the ages. On top of all these great findings, Hanneli Rupert added her own production: Okapi bags are also on sale in her London shop.

content.title: Swimming with the sharks, paddling with the dolphins

introduction.small: Guaranteed adrenaline with a dive into Two Oceans Aquarium and a joy ride aboard a kayak to chase humpback whales.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Swimming with the sharks, paddling with the dolphins

paragraphs.text:
If Steven Spielberg's Jaws made you smile, you may be ready to swim with the sharks! You can opt to do a shark dive (safely ensconced in a steel cage) in Shark Alley, or further away on Mossel Bay's Garden Route, in the hope of catching sight of a great white shark.
Less controversial and especially less risky, dive at the Two Oceans Aquarium at Victoria & Alfred Waterfront in Cape Town, an option that will please the whole family, witnessing your water theatrics. No white sharks there, but many unsympathetic large teeth predators… as well as penguins!
Other less dramatic confrontations with nature can be made on a kayak. You can see humpback whales (generally between July and December), seals, penguins, and even dolphins. Some of these animals are curious enough to swim along with you. A magical moment for the entire family!

content.title: Table Mountain National Park, nature straight up

introduction.small: A hike up the Western Cape mountain will reward you with an unparalleled view of the peninsula.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Table Mountain National Park, nature straight up

paragraphs.text:
The ‘face' of Table Mountain indeed has its expressions; it seems to be smiling kindly when the sun is out, but becomes almost worrying once plunged into the shadows or in the black of night. The mood of Cape Town and its weather indeed depends, in part, on this mysterious mountain overlooking the city. Are there clouds running along its flanks like a snake?

Get out your umbrellas! Table Mountain is announcing rain. Now part of the New7Wonders of Nature, as chosen by a global poll, the base of this magnificent mountain reaches all the way to the foam of the ocean. The Table Mountain National Park covers 220 square kilometres from Signal Hill in the north to Cape Point in the south. You can take the Cableway that has climbed to the summit since 1929, or lace up your boots and walk. In this case, allow for at least two and a half hours and get ready for some muscular pain the following morning!

content.title: South African National Gallery, journey through local culture

introduction.small: A must-see stop for both the permanent collection and the temporary exhibits, displaying African and international arts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: South African National Gallery, journey through local culture

paragraphs.text:
Besides a visit to the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa (Zeitz MOCAA), you have to discover the rich corridors of the South African National Gallery.

In the centre of the city, hidden in the greenery of Company's Garden park, the 1930 building houses a permanent collection of British, Dutch, Flemish, French, and African art. Indeed, African art, which was long the poor relation of the gallery, is finally getting the recognition it deserves, thanks to the museum's updated acquisition policy. Indigenous sculptures and elaborate beadwork are one part of the African art on display here. The National Gallery is also requesting the return of objects that were taken abroad during apartheid.

Among the contemporary works, Jane Alexander's The Butcher Boys featuring 'hybrid' men with animal parts on their bodies evokes a society traumatised after years of apartheid. Have a look and take a moment to reflect…

content.title: Panthera Africa, feline sanctuary

introduction.small: An incredible "retirement home" for lions, panthers, tigers and other felines: challenge met, for two South African pasionaria.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Panthera Africa, feline sanctuary

paragraphs.text:
One of the founders of Panthera Africa worked on a farm with animals in captivity; the other was a businesswoman who travelled extensively and led a glamorous life. Lizaene Cornwall and Cathrine Nyquist created this sanctuary for injured or endangered felines in 2015 to live out their true passion: to treat their feline friends with respect. Their goal? To offer these 'big cats' a life of rest and to save them from unnatural deaths.

On their 40-hectare property, 23 animals including lions, tigers, caracals and leopards, occupy ten hectares. You will get to see them up close behind a circular enclosure. The tour lasts 90 minutes to two hours and will give you the opportunity to learn more about all aspects of the cats' lives, including what happens on farms that promote controlled hunting in South Africa, an activity condemned by Panthera Africa. As Kruger Park is far from Cape Town, this visit is an alternative to familiarise you with these precious African treasures.

Even more so, as the drive here, less than two hours from the city, provides the opportunity to see some stunning scenery.

content.title: Victoria & Alfred Waterfront: let the renewal begin

introduction.small: Undergoing redevelopment, the seafront is perfect for a stroll up to the Zeitz MOCAA Museum, brand new museum of African contemporary art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Victoria & Alfred Waterfront: let the renewal begin

paragraphs.text:
All tourists' explorations, at one time or another, lead to the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront, if only to embark on the boat for Robben Island. As the port is still active here, there is much to be seen, with Table Mountain looming in the background.

Built in 1860, the district had its golden days before falling into disrepair. Now it is in full recovery. Today the area is again on the crest of a wave: the architect Heinrich Wolff has redeveloped the former Blue Shed market. Renamed Watershed, the building has been reimagined as a long street bordered by little stands presenting a beautiful array of African design and handmade goods. But that's not all.

In 2017, the Zeitz MOCAA, the first contemporary art museum in South Africa and largest African contemporary art museum in the world, opened its doors here in a former grain silo. Arranged inside the 42 remaining cylinders and concrete wells, the structure offers 18 exhibition rooms spread over 6,000 sqm, as well as a sculpture garden, several restaurants, a shop and a hotel. Where will you start?

http://zeitzmocaa.museum/

content.title: Robben Island, a moving trip to Nelson Mandela's prison

introduction.small: A few kilometres away from the continent, discover this island prison, symbol of South Africa's history and pilgrimage site.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Robben Island, a moving trip to Nelson Mandela's prison

paragraphs.text:
One still arrives by boat, in a very organised fashion, to this famous but sad island, where Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison before being freed in 1990.

Of course, tourists have replaced the guards and prisoners, but the bars are still on the windows, witnesses to the institution's previous vocation. In fact, a former prisoner explains the daily lives of the prison's ex-‘residents'. Telling of forced labour and a lack of food to straight-out harassment, his descriptions will give you goose bumps. Look into cell 466/64, which is the most photographed. It measures 2.1 x 2.4 metres. Nelson Mandela could barely move inside it.

Other cells of Section A held hard-core political prisoners. Perhaps concentrating them together helped them to dream of another world, without apartheid. The prison in this sense could be seen as a political laboratory, one that helped educate Mandela, who would become president from 1994 to 1999.

content.title: Bo-Kaap, a rainbow of facades to bring up the past

introduction.small: Enter the Malay district and lose yourself in its charming cobblestone streets. A journey through time…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bo-Kaap, a rainbow of facades to bring up the past

paragraphs.text:
Yellow, red, orange, blue, green the brightly painted Bo-Kaap facades are probably the most photographed in Cape Town, especially those on Chiappini, Rose, and Wale Streets. The area did not always have reason to be so cheerful.

Slaves, prisoners, and political exiles, mostly Muslims, settled here as of 1658, with many freed slaves arriving after 1834. They began to call this neighbourhood ‘Malay' at this time, even though the Malay slaves were a minority. The Bo-Kaap Museum traces the history of the neighbourhood and the arrival of the Muslim minority, many of whom were exiles from East Africa or South Asia. One of the oldest mosques in Cape Town is here, the Auwal Masjid, dating from 1804.

During your trip, you might hear the song of the muezzin from one of the dozen other mosques that are nearby. Under the terrible laws of apartheid, non-Muslims were forced to leave the neighbourhood.

content.title: Babylonstoren: one of the oldest farms in Cape Town

introduction.small: A stylish day in the country, between fruit picking and colourful food tasting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Babylonstoren: one of the oldest farms in Cape Town

paragraphs.text:
Karen Roos is rarely absent from the pages of interior-design magazines. Once editor of Elle Decoration South Africa, she and her husband used her talents in their renovation of a 17th-century Dutch farm, transformed into a trendy hotel. Artfully restored, the farm was quickly displayed in the pages of the thoroughly subjugated press.

And for good reason. The white buildings with nine rooms and six cottages, planted in the middle of an impressive 200-hectare garden, are decorated with perfectly chosen designer furniture and antiques.

Guests are invited to pick their own fruit and vegetables if they like. The Babel restaurant serves menus of different colours (green, yellow, and red) with ingredients from the gardens here and from neighbouring farms. At teatime inside the aptly named Greenhouse restaurant, you can taste homemade buttermilk scones and infusions made from plants grown on the premises. Stay at the Farm Hotel to also enjoy the Spa and swimming pool, and enjoy a canoe outing.

content.title: The Pot Luck Club: a culinary treasure

introduction.small: This second address of the brilliant Luke Dale-Roberts proposes a trip around the world through tapas-style shared dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pot Luck Club: a culinary treasure

paragraphs.text:
If you can't get a table at the famous The Test Kitchen, The Pot Luck Club may be your ‘lucky' card, and it's right nearby. Opened in 2012, this restaurant is nestled on the top floor of The Old Biscuit Mill and offers breath-taking views over the city. But the real show here, better than the best reality TV, is the open kitchen where the brigade bustles around a 1.4-metre Robata grill while wielding a battery of woks.

Revisited tapas come in the five tastes: salty, sour, bitter, sweet, and umami, an idea of ​​Luke Dale-Roberts after his many travels in South America, Europe, Asia, and Africa. Dishes are meant to be shared, which adds to the conviviality of the place. He has developed a Sunday brunch as well. And if, again, all the tables are booked, you can have a cocktail at sunset, or even try Naturalis, one of the chef's alternative addresses.

content.title: The Grand Daddy Hotel, a voyage in and of itself

introduction.small: The road of dreams with vintage trailers perched on the hotel roof.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Grand Daddy Hotel, a voyage in and of itself

paragraphs.text:
While the classic rooms of The Grand Daddy Hotel are just lovely, you really ought to ask for the key to one of seven vintage Airstream trailers parked… on the 4th floor! On the hotel's roof, they create a dreamlike scenery that will take you far from home.

Each room has its own style, from the ‘Grape Escape', with its wine-inspired scenery, to the ‘Gold Rush', ‘Bloomin' Daisies', or any of the others, all of which illustrate aspects of South African history and heritage. No matter which option you choose, you will fall asleep in the comfort of a real vintage trailer. Continuing the theme of the road, every Monday night the hotel organises ‘drive-in' evenings, with an outdoor cinema on the rooftop.

You will have a front row seat for the 8:00 p.m. show as long as you reserve on the Internet or at the front desk. On other nights, enjoy a drink at the Daddy Cool or Sky bars. You will feel cool indeed.

content.title: First Thursdays, the new Saturday night

introduction.small: Once a month in Cape Town, weekends start on Thursday with this festive cultural tour of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: First Thursdays, the new Saturday night

paragraphs.text:
Do as the locals do and head out on the town the first Thursday of the month. Art galleries, cultural sites, and design studios are open until 9:00 p.m. or later. Cape Towners gather ideas, drink up emotions, and love to run into each other. It's a pretext to get together and enjoy a night out.

The organisers offer a selection of places and events, close enough to each other that one can wander from one to the other on foot. It is still recommended to check them online beforehand. Bree and Church streets are often included, though areas from anywhere in the city can be highlighted at any time.

From food trucks to good restaurants, accompanied by performances or concerts, a lively ambiance is the only constant. Initially started in London by the Whitechapel Gallery, First Thursdays offer an occasion to discover a selection of galleries handpicked in advance, as well as to re-appropriate the public space, a great step for this city.

http://first-thursdays.co.za/

content.title: Kensington Place, off on its own

introduction.small: Trendy and intimate, Kensington Place enjoys a perfect location near the city parks, gardens and galleries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kensington Place, off on its own

paragraphs.text:
With just eight rooms, all surrounded by greenery, this boutique hotel opts for intimacy here in the Higgovale district, a haven of peace. The address is ideal for an urban retreat, just steps from the excitement of Kloff Street and its bars and restaurants.

Simple and contemporary rooms with neutral colours open onto a balcony. Guests appreciate watching the sunrise over Table Mountain. Full marks for breakfast served all day long; late risers will be happy for the option to have some coffee before a dip in the small swimming pool or a few hours on one of the sun loungers.

At Kensington Place, everything you need is here, including even the smallest details: a nice selection of DVDs, a local cell phone available for you to use, and even coupons for a nearby gym. Little extras like this make for a pleasant stay.

content.title: The Roundhouse Restaurant, classical elegance

introduction.small: Contemporary South African and European cuisine served in a refined setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Roundhouse Restaurant, classical elegance

paragraphs.text:
For more than two centuries, the Roundhouse has looked out over the Cape across from Lion's Head.

First a gatehouse then a hunting lodge, this rustic rotunda is now a very popular restaurant. Its interiors combine 18th-century flooring, Nguni chairs by Philippe Starck, and bay windows opening onto the ocean. The kitchen honours the freshest South African ingredients with European- and African-inspired dishes. A sommelier selects the appropriate wine for your dishes from a cellar composed of great local wines.

Lunch and cocktails at dusk are taken in the shade of pomegranate trees, on the “Rumbullion” terrace. The name means ‘joyful moment' in 16th-century English slang. And indeed it is.
